Constraints¶

All constraints of a task must be fulfilled immediately when the status of the task is changed to Execution. If at least one constraint is violated, the task will be set to Discarded immediately.

Normally, constraints are checked against the task. If the constraint is assigned to a briefcase, it is checked against this briefcase instead.

Defining Constraints for Single Tasks¶

In the details are of a task, you can specify one or more constraints. An example use case could be: “All objects of a folder must be released”. Select the appropriate constraint and the corresponding briefcase. Only if all objects of the briefcase are actually released when the task is started, the task is considered relevant and remains in status Execution.

You can invert the constraint to make the task in the above example run only if not all objects are released, i.e. if at least one object’s status differs.

The constraints of a task are connected logically by the operator “AND”. This means that all constraints must be fulfilled for the task to be executed.

Defining Constraints for Task Groups¶

A constraint can also be defined for an entire task group. To do so, click on the constraint symbol at the branch that marks the beginning of the task group. Defining constraints will then be the same as for individual tasks.

Included Constraint Rules¶

The following table shows all included Objektregeln for the definition of constraints. Not listed are rules for other purposes, such as the representation in CONTACT Tasks or filter rules.

Rule Description Checked Against
wf-designer: previous process component done Fulfilled for tasks whose predecessor’s status is Completed. The predecessor is either the task with the next smaller position of the parent element or the predecessor of the parent element (if available). If no predecessor exists, or if it has a different status, the rule is violated. Task
wf-designer: all briefcase objects approved Fulfilled if all briefcases to be checked do not contain objects that are not released. By default, only documents and items are considered. Additional objects can be set up by specifying additional predicates. Task, Briefcase
wf-designer: all previous tasks done Fulfilled if all predecessors (all children of a previous parallel task group are considered) are in status Completed. Always violated for briefcases. Task
wf-designer: all process tasks have start date and deadline Fulfilled for a workflow if all of its tasks (not task groups) have non-empty attributes start_date and deadline. Workflow
wf-designer: briefcase contains exactly 1 object Fulfilled if the briefcase contains exactly one object. Briefcase
wf-designer: parent’s previous process component done Fulfilled if the status of the predecessor of the parent task group is Completed. Violated if there is no parent task group or if it has no predecessor. Task
wf-designer: process completing successfully Fulfilled if the workflow is not currently being cancelled. Task, Briefcase

Note

Your system administrator may define additional rules.
